revision.text:
{{Infobox military person | name = Caleb Thayer Bailey | image = | caption = | birth_date = August 28, 1898 | death_date = January 13, 1957 (aged 58) | birth_place = [[Bladensburg, Maryland]] | death_place = [[San Diego, California]] | placeofburial = | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = | nickname = "Zeke" | birth_name = | allegiance = {{US}} | branch = [[File:USMC logo.svg|23px]] [[United States Marine Corps]] | serviceyears = | rank = [[File:US-O7 insignia.svg|20px]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] | servicenumber = | unit = | commands = [[Marine Corps Air Depot Miramar]]
[[Marine Aircraft Group 11]] | battles = [[World War II]]
[[Korean War]] | battles_label = Wars | awards = | relations = | laterwork = | signature = }} Brigadier General '''Caleb Thayer "Zeke" Bailey''' (August 28, 1898 – January 13, 1957) was an American [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]] officer, pilot, and athlete. Bailey was the first commander of [[Marine Corps Air Depot Miramar]], and served as a commander of [[Marine Aircraft Group 11]] during the [[Pacific War|War in the Pacific]]. Bailey was inducted into the [[University of Maryland Athletic Hall of Fame]] in 1984. ==Early life== A native of [[Bladensburg, Maryland]],[http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0E17FA3854107B93C7AB178AD95F478485F9 Bombs Stun Japanese], ''The New York Times'', November 24, 1943. Bailey attended the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]], where he became a member of the Beta Kappa chapter of the [[Kappa Alpha Order]].[http://www.kappaalphaorder.org/repository/ASSETS/PDF/kaj-WINT09_v4.pdf We Serve, Vol. II], p. 15, ''Kappa Alpha Journal'', 2009. He was a regular on the [[Maryland Terrapins football|UM Terrapins football team]] from 1918 to 1922.[http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/md/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/07guide-11.pdf All-Time Lettermen] (PDF), ''2007 Terrapin Football Record Book'', p. 17, University of Maryland, 2007. A dedicated sportsman, he played in the 1921 season while recovering from a broken jaw.{{Cite news |last= |first= |date=November 13, 1921 |title=Maryland–Catholic U. Game |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3002989// |newspaper=[[The Washington Herald]] |location=Washington, DC |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |accessdate=August 12, 2015 }} {{Open access}} ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'' wrote in 1922 that Bailey was among those "men whose work can be attributed much of the Black and Gold's success of the last few years."[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1656842902.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Dec+06%2C+1922&author=&pub=The+Sun+%281837-1985%29&desc=Eight+Dependable+Players+Will+Be+Lost+From+The+University+Of+Maryland+Football+Team&pqatl=google Eight Dependable Players Will Be Lost From The University Of Maryland Football Team; Their Absence Is Keenly Felt Much Of Recent Success Attributed To Outgoing Gridmen TO ELECT A CAPTAIN Fullback Jack McQuade Mentioned As Leader For 1923], ''The Baltimore Sun'', December 6, 1922. He also played on the [[Maryland Terrapins baseball|Maryland baseball team]] as a [[catcher (baseball)|catcher]].[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1656386712.html?FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Feb+27%2C+1922&author=&pub=The+Sun+%281837-1985%29&desc=College+Parkers+Plan+For+Grind+On+Diamond&pqatl=google College Parkers Plan For Grind On Diamond], ''The Baltimore Sun'', February 27, 1922. In May 1923, he tried out for the [[Newark Bears (1926–1949)|Newark Bears]], a professional baseball team in the [[International League]].[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1797550682.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=May+28%2C+1923&author=&pub=The+Sun+%281837-1985%29&desc=Parnham+Has+No+One+To+Blame&pqatl=google Parnham Has No One To Blame But Himself For Bird Defeat Big Pitcher Fails To Take Advantage Of Opportunities -- Johnny Honig Responsible For Six Runs -- Dunn Again At The Park], ''The Baltimore Sun'', May 28, 1923. ==Military career== After college, Bailey entered the [[United States Marine Corps]]. He played on the [[Quantico Marines]] football team as a [[center (American football)|center]] from 1923 to 1926. After the Marines defeated [[Fort Benning]] in November 1926, Bailey received the President's Cup from First Lady [[Grace Coolidge]] on behalf of his team.[http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00B1EFE3C5D13738DDDA80A94D9415B868EF1D3 MRS. COOLIDGE SEES QUANTICO TRIUMPH; Marines Defeat Fort Benning, 27 to 7, and Win Service Title for Second Year. FIRST LADY PRESENTS CUP She Represents President at Game, Dividing Her Time Between Rooting Sections. MRS. COOLIDGE SEES QUANTICO TRIUMPH], ''The New York Times'', November 21, 1926. In 1928 and 1929, he served as an assistant coach for Quantico.[http://jarheadjocks.com/doc/FootballTeams1918-42-2.pdf Quantico Football: 1918 thru 1942] (PDF), Quantico Marine Athletes Reunion Group, retrieved September 3, 2010. In December 1938, he was promoted from [[captain (United States)|captain]] to [[major (United States)|major]].[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1779886592.html?FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Dec+20%2C+1938&author=&pub=The+Sun+%281837-1985%29&desc=3+Marylanders+Given+Promotions+In+Marines&pqatl=google 3 Marylanders Given Promotions In Marines], ''The Baltimore Sun'', December 20, 1938. As a [[lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]], Bailey served in the Municipal Police Commission of [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|St. Thomas]] and [[Saint John, U.S. Virgin Islands|St. John]] in the [[United States Virgin Islands]], until he resigned to take another post in December 1942.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ragdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nUMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4353,4166976&dq=caleb-bailey+marine&hl=en Governor Appoints Col. Major To Police Commission], ''The Virgin Islands Daily News'', December 8, 1942. As a [[colonel (United States)|colonel]], Bailey oversaw the establishment of [[Marine Corps Air Station Miramar|Marine Corps Air Depot Miramar]] on September 2, 1943 and served as its first commander.[http://www.usmc.mil/news/publications/Documents/A%20Chronology%20Of%20The%20United%20States%20Marine%20Corps%201935-1946%20%20PCN%2019000317800.pdf ''A Chronology Of The United States Marine Corps 1935-1946''], p. 51, History and Museums Division, Headquarters, U.S. Marine Corps, 1965. During [[World War II]], the base provided logistical support to Marine Corps aviation units as they prepared to deploy to combat.Robert Lee Sherrod, [https://books.google.com/books?id=WrchAQAAIAAJ&q=%22caleb+t+bailey%22&dq=%22caleb+t+bailey%22&hl=en&ei=AJiATPKgKIKC8gbRmIirAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBQ ''History of Marine Corps aviation in World War II''], p. 441, Nautical & Aviation Pub. Co. of America, 1987, ISBN 0-933852-58-4. Bailey commanded [[Marine Aircraft Group 11]] in the [[Palau]]s, which provided [[close air support]] to the [[81st Infantry Division (United States)|81st Infantry Division]] and [[1st Marine Division (United States)|1st Marine Division]] during the [[Pacific War|War in the Pacific]].[http://www.mca-marines.org/gazette/pacific-war-%E2%80%93-1941-1945 The Pacific War – 1941-1945: Peleliu], ''Marine Corps Gazette'', November 1985.[http://www.mca-marines.org/gazette/forum/wwii?page=1 Naval War in the Pacific in 1944], ''Marine Corps Gazette'', March 1945. While group commander of MAG-11 at [[Peleliu]], his pilots of [[VMF-122]] began what they called "Operation Freeze". In these missions, a single [[Vought F4U Corsair|F4U Corsair]] flew at 30,000 to 33,000 feet to practice high-altitude operations, which also had the side benefits of drawing ineffective Japanese [[anti-aircraft artillery]] fire (thereby wasting their ammunition stores), and creating ten gallons of chocolate [[ice cream]]. The field-expedient dessert was made from a concoction of [[evaporated milk|canned milk]] and [[cocoa solids|cocoa powder]] stored in an underwing tank, which froze during flight at the high altitude. According to the book ''Corsair: The F4U in World War II and Korea'', Bailey called the unit and told them, "You guys aren't fooling me, I've got spies. You tell Hunter I'm coming over there tomorrow and get my ration."Barrett Tillman, [https://books.google.com/books?id=JqRIaIn1LFgC ''Corsair: The F4U in World War II and Korea''], pp. 85–86, Naval Institute Press, 2002, ISBN 1-55750-994-8. During the [[Korean War]], he served as the Chief of Staff of the [[1st Marine Aircraft Wing]].Ed Dailey, [https://books.google.com/books?id=GQUDyaabergC ''MacArthur's X Corps in Korea: Inchon to the Yalu, 1950''], p. 132, Turner Publishing Company, 1999, ISBN, 1563114399. Bailey retired from the Marine Corps with the rank of [[brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]]. He died on January 13, 1957 at the [[Bob Wilson Naval Hospital|Naval Hospital]] in [[San Diego]], [[California]] at the age of 58.[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1689444052.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Jan+15%2C+1957&author=&pub=The+Sun+%281837-1985%29&desc=GEN.+BAILEY+DIES+AT+58&pqatl=google GEN. BAILEY DIES AT 58; Ex-Marine Flyer, U. Of M. Star, Was III In San Diego], ''The Baltimore Sun'', January 15, 1957.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dqwpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5vYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4398,2805107&dq=zeke-bailey&hl=en One-Minute Sports Page], ''Spokane Daily Chronicle'', January 14, 1957. The [[University of Maryland Athletic Hall of Fame]] inducted him in 1984.[http://www.umterps.com/trads/md-wall-of-fame.html All-Time Inductees] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717160004/http://www.umterps.com/trads/md-wall-of-fame.html |date=July 17, 2011 }}, University of Maryland Athletic Hall of Fame, retrieved August 30, 2010. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bailey, Caleb}} [[Category:1890s births]] [[Category:1957 deaths]] [[Category:People from Bladensburg, Maryland]] [[Category:Maryland Terrapins football players]] [[Category:Maryland Terrapins baseball players]] [[Category:Quantico Marines Devil Dogs football players]] [[Category:United States Marine Corps generals]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Korean War]] [[Category:Players of American football from Maryland]] [[Category:Baseball players from Maryland]]
